Plan B, also called the morning-after pill or emergency contraception, has been available by prescription since 1999.
Plan B is actually two pills.
They contain the same ingredients as birth control pills, and when the pills are taken within 72 hours of sex, they are quite effective in preventing pregnancy.
In 2003, BARR Pharmaceuticals, Plan B's maker, tried to get the FDA to allow Plan B to be sold over the counter.
FDA advisory committees looked at the issue and voted 23-to-4 to allow over-the-counter sales.
But the FDA ignored that recommendation, citing concerns about the effect that selling Plan B over the counter might have on the sexual activity of teens.
The drugmaker came back with a plan to have the drugs sold over the counter only to women over 16.
And now nearly two years into the debate, the FDA has yet to act.
In late August, they announced they had made no decision one way or the other and instead opened a 60-day public comment period.
The FDA's failure to act on Plan B prompted the agency's director of women's health, Susan Wood, to resign in protest.

In an e-mail to colleagues, Dr. Wood said, quote, ""I can no longer serve as staff when scientific and clinical evidence fully evaluated and recommended for approval by the professional staff has been overruled.
So what happened?
Why did the FDA decide not to heed the advice of its own advisory committees?
Some say the agency buckled to political pressure from social conservatives who are opposed to contraception or who view Plan B as causing abortions.
Did ideology trump science in this case?
Or does the FDA have legitimate reasons to keep Plan B from going over the counter?
